column4: i would like to check which packages i have installed *and* which packages are installed by default so i can figure out what i've added to setup somebody else's box very similar to mine
what do you mean by "default" .. during the install process you usually say what kind of packages to install
the closest you could get is the list of essential packages
something like that
i know every time i install i have to get build essential and *-dev
easier would just be to get your list and their list and see what's missing, don't worry about the "default"
so any overlap won't cause problems?
problems with what?
such as a 386 kernel installing by default and me now using a 686smp kernel
hmm
my guess is there aren't many things like that.. but, it doesn't really matter if both kernels are installed
i'd be worried that installing from a beastly list of packages could be a bad thing if some of the low-level stuff doesn't match up
that's what dependencies are for :)
.me puts his faith in dependencies and will just give it a go
debian dependencies are awesome .. i assume Ubuntu is basically the same
anyway, to get a list of installed packages, you can run this on the command line: dpkg -l | grep '^ii '
thanks brainsik
or this for something cleaner: dpkg -l | grep '^ii ' | cut -f 3 -d ' '
does that carrot in '^ii ' indicate a new line?
indicates the beginning of a line
thanks a bundle.  you taught me a new command and a new regexp
:) cool!
